caption: SGBudget2025: The Home Team continues to do well in keeping Singapore safe and secure. Singaporeans remain confident in the Home Teams ability to carry out its mission fairly and effectively.To tackle new and evolving threats and security challenges, the Home Team will: Leverage technologies such as Artificial Intelligence for organisational effectiveness, equip our officers with the competencies to use them, and review our laws and regulatory frameworks to deal with crimes. Expand the foreign recruitment pool for Emergency Medical Services personnel and Auxiliary Police Officers with tight safeguards. Partner banks to strengthen their scam prevention measures and work on more ways to help people better identify potential scams. Strengthen Preventive Drug Education for youths, such as through schools and with parents. Fully operationalise Supervision 2.0 to enhance the supervision and reintegration of ex-drug abusers into society, as well as support the rehabilitation of inmates with initiatives that help them strengthen relationships with their families and enhance their chances for gainful employment.For more information, visit

caption: Multi-racialism, underpinned by racial harmony, is a foundational principle for Singapore.The state of racial harmony in Singapore is strong, and the Maintenance of Racial Harmony Bill passed in Parliament on 4 February further strengthens our ability to safeguard our social cohesion.The Bill has five key proposals. It:1. ports over existing race-related offences in the Penal Code;2. introduces the Community Remedial Initiative;3. establishes a Restraining Order regime;4. establishes the Presidential Council for Racial and Religious Harmony to advise on matters relating to racial and religious harmony that are referred to it by the Minister for Home Affairs or by Parliament; and5. introduces safeguards against malicious foreign influence via race-based entities. Learn more about the second and third proposals in the images above.Read more:go.gov.sg/racial-harmony-bill-minister-speechgo.gov.sg/racial-harmony-bill-mos-speechgo.gov.sg/racial-harmony-bill-wrap-up
cleaned_caption: Multi-racialism, underpinned by racial harmony, is a foundational principle for Singapore. The state of racial harmony in Singapore is strong, and the Maintenance of Racial Harmony Bill passed in Parliament on 4 February further strengthens our ability to safeguard our social cohesion. The Bill has five key proposals. It: 1. ports over existing race-related offences in the Penal Code; 2. introduces the Community Remedial Initiative; 3. establishes a Restraining Order regime; 4. establishes the Presidential Council for Racial and Religious Harmony to advise on matters relating to racial and religious harmony that are referred to it by the Minister for Home Affairs or by Parliament; and 5. introduces safeguards against malicious foreign influence via race-based entities. Learn more about the second and third proposals in the images above. caption: Since childhood days, Ive had the desire to be part of the uniform services and contribute to the security of our nation. These aspirations were fuelled by family and friends who had careers in SCDF, Prisons and SPF. What drove me to apply for a scholarship with the Home Team and to choose ICA was because of the diversity of roles undertaken by ICA to secure the borders. Now that Im working on the frontline at Tuas Checkpoint, I have the opportunity of working alongside other HTDs like the Police and CNB to prevent the entry of undesirable persons and goods to keep Singapore safe and secure.I also had the opportunity to work on ICAs New Clearance Concept to enhance our systems and processes, ensuring that we are ready to tackle new challenges with the evolving operating terrain. My team and I will continue to carry out our duties in a professional manner to inspire public confidence and trust in the Home Team. caption: When SGT2 Mohamad Rizuan Bin Amin first joined the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) in 2008, he was posted to the Coastal Command (Singapore Cruise Centre) as a Primary Screening Officer conducting immigration clearance at the counter. Shortly after, he joined the Clearance Team, where he had the opportunity to go out to sea to clear crew onboard sea vessels. I also dealt with drugs, contraband, illegal immigrants, and other prohibited items. One of my biggest contraband cases to date was a joint operation with other agencies in 2012 at Jurong River. Each agency played a part in nabbing those involved in the smuggling from sea (smugglers) to land (handlers and distributors), and we managed to retrieve over 2,000 cartons of contraband cigarettes at the end.It was memorable as it was a unique experience, and I felt a sense of satisfaction being part of this operation. - SGT2 Rizuan, ICA.SGT2 Rizuan was posted to Tuas Checkpoint in 2018 and is currently taking on the role of a mentor for cargo clearance and a certified Image Analyst.: .....OneHomeTeam ImmigrationandCheckpointsAuthority GuardiansofOurBorders SecureBordersSafeSG

caption: CI (2) Syed Aziz once had to deal with an aggressive subject who dashed through the immigration gates to evade immigration checks back when he was posted to Changi Airport.I was initially worried that the subject could be a major security threat, but as he seemed mentally troubled, I quickly transitioned into the role of a counsellor. Later, I understood that he was remanded at the Institute of Mental Health (IMH) and was assessed to be mentally unsound. After further investigations, he was eventually repatriated back to his home country. caption: As the Commanding Officer of Lim Chu Kang Region, SUPT Ahamed Basha is committed to making his lessons memorable so that his officers can excel in their maritime Policing duties.We were on a three-day sailing trip to Brunei in 2015 when we experienced the full force of the northeast monsoon winds. caption: The vaccination exercise for Home Team officers involved in frontline healthcare operations started this morning (11 January 2021).The first Home Team healthcare frontliner vaccinated was Warrant Officer 1 Mohamed Shafiee Bin Jamin, 38.
